description: From Old French surmis, past participle of surmetre, surmettre (“to accuse”), from sur- (“upon”) + metre (“to put”).

entries.meaning: Thought, imagination, or conjecture, which may be based upon feeble or scanty evidence; suspicion; guess.
examples: surmises of jealousy or of envy
This opinion, however, is merely a surmise, which may or may not be the case.

verbs.description: surmise (third-person singular simple present surmises, present participle surmising, simple past and past participle surmised)

entries.meaning: To imagine or suspect; to conjecture; to posit with contestable premises.
examples: If, as I surmise, you see the ladies this evening, you might mention my intended visit.
